comment: Not so great (same as in English)
the ela reading is slightly harder to get when full clauses are conjoined (in English); with ela conjoining full clauses is not so good in this context
Here, both o’s are required
Here, both o’s are required
Here, both o’s are required
probably wouldn’t choose this one (above) [but volunteered]
variant with o not very good in this context
the complementiser is needed in the second example; no second “o še-” in the clausal disjunction (this would block the FC reading)
sounds a bit weird
would be ok as a clarification
That’s ok, but the pronoun has to be there.
s.a.
well-formed but false in the context
generally bad without negation in the first conjunct
means that only one of them is a doctor
grammatical, but a little weird; might be good in certain contexts, but it would have the same meaning as the above sentence
this is ok
a bit awkward (conjoining two clauses w/o the complementizer), corrected to: O Pol o Jon hu rofe.
single ‘o’ seems unnatural in this example, not quite clear why, might be because of the copular/pronoun
strongly exclusive interpretation
this sounds a bit like you’re changing your mind (afterthought)
the following sounds better, but not sure:
The following was volunteered as the best version for this example (better with ‘o … o’ than only one ‘o’):

The following can be inclusive (difference might be about the tense/predicate type); with ‘o … o’ it would more likely be interpreted exclusively; (but the difference between single ‘o’ and ‘o … o’ might also be related to number marking)
